instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on audio board
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> when the charger is connected to the laptop is taking 5.14 volts, 0.05A and 0.25W.

The only place i found a short was on the bottom caps of the audio board but when i remove the heatsink the short is gone and the macbook works perfectly fine! could this be a bad cpu/ram ?


Any help would be appreciate it 
Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on audio board
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"when i remove the heatsink the short is gone"
Do you mean the metal cover of that connector maybe?

You should inspect audio board/flex for corrosion.
Check M1 data lines corresponding to that connector.

You should try DFU, just in case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on audio board
threads.message:
Thank you,

I mean when I remove the actual heatsink the one above the processor and the memory ram.

The audio board is brand new and the computer is now working ok without the heat sink.

I will now check the M1 data lines on the board.

Also what exactly I should try in DFU mode ?


Thank you

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on audio board
threads.message:
Forget DFU, if machine works.

Put back heatsink and look around screw holes for any damage sign.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on audio board
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 102326, member: 682"]
Forget DFU, if machine works.

Put back heatsink and look around screw holes for any damage sign.
[/QUOTE]
Hi,

I did a visual inspection under a microscope and everything seems to be working ok. I put back the heatsink and the MacBook stopped working, after I removed it again and now it works fine.

Looks like whenever the heatsink in on there is a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> but when I remove the heatsink the short is gone which makes me believe that either a component under the heatsink might be touching the heatsink causing the short or perhaps the A2 pin under <CHIP>U0600</CHIP> on the top left or maybe the pressure from the bracket might be interfering with a component connected to the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> line causing it to short to ground when the heatsink is on.

Really hope you can guide me to find the issue and get this board fixed.


Thank you

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on audio board
threads.message:
What is resistance (ohm scale) to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>?
Check it disconnecting charger and battery; allow 10-15s to discharge remanent voltage.

You may have a problem inside board.
Pressure caused by heatsink screws may cause short between the copper layers.
